udev - Linux userspace device management udev - Linux userspace device management
Integrating udev in the system has complex dependencies and may differ from Integrating udev in the system has complex dependencies and may differ from
distribution to distribution. A system may not be able to boot up or work distribution to distribution. A system may not be able to boot up or work
reliably without a properly installed udev version. The upstream udev proje ct reliably without a properly installed udev version. The upstream udev proje ct
does not recommend replacing a distro's udev installation with the upstream does not recommend replacing a distro's udev installation with the upstream
version. version.
The upstream udev project's set of default rules may require a most recent The upstream udev project's set of default rules may require a most recent
kernel release to work properly. This is currently version 2.6.32. kernel release to work properly.

Setup: Setup:
- At bootup, the /dev directory should get the 'devtmpfs' filesystem
mounted. Udev manages the permissions and ownership of the kernel-creat
ed
device nodes, and udev possibly creates additional symlinks. If needed,
udev also
works on an empty 'tmpfs' filesystem, but some device nodes like
/dev/null, /dev/console, /dev/kmsg should be created before udevd is st
arted.
- The udev daemon should be started to handle device events sent by the k ernel. - The udev daemon should be started to handle device events sent by the k ernel.

that they are configured by udev. This is usually done by: that they are configured by udev. The systemd service files contain the
/sbin/udevadm trigger --action=add --type=subsystems needed commands to start the udev daemon and the coldplug sequence.

- Restarting the daemon never applies any rules to existing devices. - Restarting the daemon never applies any rules to existing devices.
- New/changed rule files are picked up automatically; there is no daemon - New/changed rule files are picked up automatically; there is usually no
restart or signal needed. daemon restart or signal needed.
Operation: Operation:
- Based on events the kernel sends out on device creation/removal, udev - Based on events the kernel sends out on device creation/removal, udev
creates/removes device nodes and symlinks in the /dev directory. creates/removes device nodes and symlinks in the /dev directory.
- All kernel events are matched against a set of specified rules, which - All kernel events are matched against a set of specified rules, which
possibly hook into the event processing and load required kernel possibly hook into the event processing and load required kernel
modules to set up devices. For all devices, the kernel exports a major/ minor modules to set up devices. For all devices, the kernel exports a major/ minor
number; if needed, udev creates a device node with the default kernel number; if needed, udev creates a device node with the default kernel
